title: Nadiya Hussain: it frightens me now but dying seemed like a good way to end my suffering
text:
The Great British Bake Off star opens up about the childhood traumas which triggered her crushing anxiety and how a recipe of jogs, hikes and cakes is keeping her happy and healthy in her 30s

Deep into a colourful conversation about cakes, forest walks and the delicious eggs from her garden chickens, Nadiya Hussain grows uncharacteristically solemn and begins to recall the day she almost killed herself. Aged just ten, but badly traumatised after a vicious bullying campaign by schoolboys who flushed her head down the toilet and crushed her fingers in doors, she hid in her bedroom in Luton with a packet of pills and swallowed one. Then another. And another.

"It frightens me now because I have...
